eXZx8AL775pExdv8DQztUQ.text: The Edinburgh Larder prides itself on stocking quality local (Scottish) deli produce: cheese, chutney, jams, pickles, oils, beer, wines, sprits, fizz, oat cakes, salami, smoked chicken, hot smoked salmon, tablet, honey, biscuits  and that is just scratching the surface of what they have to offer. But the Edinburgh Larder isn't just a deli, its a cafe and a restaurant (with Eteaket Tea and Artisan Roast coffe). Located on Blackfriars Street (just off the Royal Mile) it is perfectly placed for tourists and workers in the east end of town, and if you find yourself nearby I definitely recommend stopping in for a freshly prepared sandwich or home made soup  so get yourself there and taste what Scotland growers and farmers have to offer! I didn't even know this place existed until a recent Qype beer (Stewarts), cheese and chutney tasting evening. The staff are knowledgeable about their stock, and matched the cheese and chutney with a Stewarts beer for a very tasty experience. The Applewood smoked cheddar was divine, and the fresh chutney, and spicy pumpkin (yes, pumpkin!) chutney, were a revelation! Now that I have discovered this wee gem, I will be back time and time again. Edinburgh Larder can be booked for private functions, and also run a number of events  Nordic dinners, foraging courses, and allotment BBQ's all of which sound delicious and interesting!

7slZ3bxb9q_qffrD9wI_zA.text: I've read about The Larder before, but had never come across it whilst stumbling around Edinburgh so was excited to attend a event here. Oh, and what is it that we'll be sampling here in particular? CHEESE?! Yes flipping please! As you will have probably read in the reviews by other event attendees, it was a tantalising set up; four cheeses with four complementing beers and condiments (predominantly chutney, but with a sneaky delicious oil thrown into the bargain). I liked EVERYTHING! Okay, to be more discerning I would say the smoked applewood cheddar won the cheese battle, the spicy pumpkin chutney tickled my condiment tastebuds and the beer that went down the most swiftly was the Edinburgh Gold. I've found myself on the Royal Mile before with visitors in tow with not a clue where to pop in for a lunchtime snack. The result has been a disappointing toastie somewhere, made out of cardboard bread and bright orange cheese and paying far too much for it. I'm glad I know this place now, as it's the first place I'll head in future with demanding and hungry guests to ensure we get some decent snap worthy of the city we are dining in. Thanks for having me, Edinburgh Larder and Qype , it was a great event.

rY-DnKiYqz1eexvVm3sZzA.text: Tried to go for lunch here once but it was packed full so wasn't able to. I did manage to get my name on the list for the qype event though  a cheese, chutney and beer tasting night. The deli/cafe put on a great spread of 4 cheeses (a couple of nice cheddars followed by a goat's cheese and my favourite  the smoked applewood) accompanied by homemade chutneys and 4 beers from the Stewart brewery (Holyrood, Edinburgh Gold, Embra and St Giles). Our hosts were very friendly and explained each of the 4 courses. Overall had a great night and will definitly be back for more. thanks a lot to the Edinburgh Larder, Stewarts brewery and Qype.

e9UBGa0CQdOcFnWPhIWO2Q.text: I had a great afternoon tea here recently!  Perhaps the nicest scone I've consumed in quite a while, a very tasty sandwich (venison salami), a pleasant brownie, and a pot of tea, all for a reasonable price.  The place is cozy and clean and I'm already planning to go back again as soon as possible.

yCPCsyHtBkl6QyBmbnacZQ.text: Excellent!  This little cafe is only failing in that it isn't bigger and away from the crowds.  It has lovely food, and hard to find products.  One needs to secure a table to enjoy the great tastes.  They have great sandwich deals, salads, soups, and authentic local/Scottish products.

bPAurfJJ-NE8r_O-fZkoFg.text: I attended my very first Qype tasting event at The Edinburgh Larder. Cheese, Chutney and Beer (Stewarts Brewery) were the order of the day. Prior to each tasting our hosts provided information on the origins of the cheese, and the brewing of the beer. Everything served was delicious, with the standouts being the award winning Holyrood Beer and the smoked cheese. Im not much of a chutney man but the home made selections complimented the cheese perfectly. The place itself is very clean with a welcoming atmosphere. The friendly and knowledgeable staff serve fresh Scottish produce, and unusually for a cafe, loads of alcohol  definitely a good thing! Next time im in the vicinity in wont take much to tempt me in for a bite and maybe (!) a wee tipple.

CGEeLjvL_uZFoQPipgEGKg.text: One of the nicest, most thoughtful presents I ever received was a little paper bag with 'The Edinburgh Larder' inscribed on it, containing a variety of lovely goodies from this fantastic delicatessen.  In the bag, was a tin of Eteaket Elderflower tea, a small glass jar of Scottish honey which I assume was made for the Larder itself, and a box of rough Scottish oatcakes, which were absolutely the nicest I have ever tasted. This deli is supplied by Eteaket amongst other local suppliers, and as well as gorgeous jars of lovely sweet stuffs, they have cheeses and meats, including some more unusual things such as venison salami, which I can vouch for being tasty!   The deli adjoins a lovely wee cafe, serving up breakfasts and lunches, including sandwiches, soups and salads. As I said, the tea is supplied bt Eteaket, and the coffee by nearby Artisan Roast, which means you are getting the best of local produce, making a lunch here doubly as enjoyable.

ArROn1W4nm8z5-rNwgdJMg.text: I never knew Edinburgh Larder existed and so as a newbie was keen to attend my first ever event  and I have to admit I was certainly not disappointed. We were made to feel very welcome and were soon sampling the four cheeses, chutneys and beers at the same time learning a bit about them all as well as the origin of Edinburgh Larder. There was even a representative from Stewart's Brewery to tell us all about the beers. Some of the products were not to my taste but that's to be expected, although at the same time I was pleasantly surprised  I'm not a fan of goat's cheese but the Inverloch Goats Cheese was actually not bad! My favourites were the Isle of Kintyre Applewood Smoked cheese, the spicy pumpkin chutney and the Edinburgh Gold beer. I didn't even know Stewart's Brewery existed, let alone that it was in Midlothian so as well as having a great night out and meeting new friends, it was also very informative. The staff could not have made us feel any more welcome and were keen to answer any questions we had. I shall definitely be paying Edinburgh Larder another visit very soon. A very successful night, glad I'm now an official qyper and roll on the next event!

9RAB81vvveyVhP2PmHSe7w.text: Had heard of this little place on one of these sites that offer you cheap deals. I didn't buy the cheap deal but, after my Qype event last week where we sampled lots of cheese and wine, do I now wish I had! Lovely little place, very clean, and the owner really knew her stuff about her cheeses and chutneys. She was very friendly and explained things very clearly. The cheeses were amazing  particularly the smoked one  and the chutneys were a lovely accompaniment. There was also a chap from Stewart's brewery who had matched beers to the cheeses  what a revelation! Not one to consume beer on the whole (nice glass of dry white wine thanks) I was amazed how nice they were with the cheeses. He also really knew his stuff and the whole event was great. Will definitely be back to this little shop  as early as this Saturday in fact as my daughter is mad keen to go there for some cheese and to buy her partner some of that lovely beer. I feel it my duty to take her. Go there  it's great.

NNXUVzejqP9X-22TqQarLg.text: the coffee here is cracking! using artisan roast, fitting with their ethic of using local providers, the flat white i tried was marvelous. rich, soft, robust, round, delicious. perfect temperature, perfect cup size. edinburgh larder is spot on and all foodies (and coffee lovers) will find joy here :) edinburghcoffeelovers.bl... twitter: @edinburghcoffee

Kl6esm9n_yHPSXqbQEh7RA.text: If you are in Edinburgh Scotland and thinking that all the best pubs, coffee shops and restaurants are on the Royal Mile you are sadly mistaken and need to look down the side street. At the Edinburgh Larder my wife and I just had coffee and asked two of the best employees if they could put together a take out meal. They set us up with the best arrangement I have ever had,  We took it all up to our wonderful holiday flat on the Royal Mile and dinned on the most wonderful tasting meal. The beet salad was spectacular (who would have ever thought that beets could taste that good) we topped off with an egg frittata and fish cakes with other wonderfully prepared cold sides. Price was so reasonable I thought they missed charging me for something.  This take away meal feed three adults, they included a chocolate treat that alone will make us return for that morsel alone.  This place is but one part of a larger Bistro that we hope to eat at soon.

iECDRoBe_inAFeRt5TeaLg.text: coffee is cracking! using artisan roast, fitting with their ethic of using local providers, the flat white i tried was marvelous. rich, soft, robust, round, delicious. perfect temperature, perfect cup size. edinburgh larder is spot on and all foodies (and coffee lovers) will find joy here :)

rH3v-wHpQ9aE658vFsQlPw.text: absolutely wonderful place. My friends and i go there now and again. Would recommend to anyone who hasnt tried it

jiCAtMqlkIgu1m4P1eAjOw.text: Tops for locally sourced fresh produce and tasty snacks, lunches etc. The selection of Scottish cheeses is just exceptional. Obviously a lot of hard work has been carried out in sourcing their stock. Worth a visit!

HqZMZKePTvZlChHel4YQbw.text: Great Scottish food served with friendly service only yards from the Royal Mile. We had wonderful local cheese, homemade chutney and several bottles of really nice beer of different varieties from Stewarts micro brewery.

T9zurYgRRyh5DKARO0KV1Q.text: I had never been to the Edinburgh Larder before, but after my first Qype event I will definitely be going back! The cafe is very quaint and the staff are lovely. After trying a selection of their cheeses, I have decided to go back to purchase some of there Smoked Applewood! Though I don't tend to be a beer person, I enjoyed sampling a couple of the beers the Edinburgh Larder staff had picked out to compliment the cheeses. Very nice and I hear they are staying open later during the festival, so will be a good place to stop by when on the royal mile. :)

qhq1Z54z3x49DT4i1fp61w.text: Absolutely delicious! One of our best meals while In Edinburgh!!! The freshest in season ingredients. I had a delicious soup of the day cauliflower and turmeric along with a half chicken sandwich which was out of this world. My husband had a sausage roll with a salad. The coffee was outstanding. I did notice a yummy looking banana bread which I wish I had ordered.  The staff is so wonderful and so amazing!  I asked one of the staff members on what we should see in Edinburgh and she suggested Arthur Seat which we did today! I highly suggest u get there before 3pm it seems there last hour and a half is open for cake and coffee. Thank you to all of you for your kindness smile and amazing food!! Our favorite place in Edinburgh !

piFPLR5JUY97gDOw5Ia8Nw.text: Let me start off by saying it that The Endinburgh Larder excels in every manner a restaurant should. They are always busy it would seem and I had to have my name put down and return in 15 min to even get a table for one. I don't mind waiting at all for the right food and this wait was not only short but warranted given the food I was served. The place is very trendy in its looks and is small and light but beautiful and fashionable.   The food  I ordered the brioche on eggs with fresh squeezed orange juice. Many times places will claim to have fresh squeezed but just give you canned orange juice, this was not that. The orange juice here was premium actually fresh squeezed and only 2.5. The eggs I asked to have both bacon and berries and the staff accommodated enthusiastically. For only 9.5 I received 2 good tasting cinnamon and sugar cooked omelette like eggs bounded atop brioche breads topped with bacon, sugar, and syrup. I cant say of the syrup was real as there was not much and there was no extra syrup provided of which to pour from. If the staff does read this that would be my only quarrel, possibly including extra real syrup to pour on top would be awesome! The dish had strawberries and blueberries as well that were caramelized meaning they rested in sugar just prior and were soft and sweet! I loved the dish the presentation I found to be worthy of any food blogger.   The staff I was served by a fashionably dressed blonde gal in overalls who was honest to god sweet, enthusiastic, and accommodating. Bless her she is doing an amazing job. I would only ask that in the future she might check in to ask how the food is being taken and if it is to guest satisfaction which she fid not do to me. However still she was an amazing waitstaff that did a swell job.  This place at the time of writing is #1 on Yelp in the area for breakfast and it shows. I encourage anyone reading to go give it a try, you will not regret it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Restaurant back end
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Brioche and eggs
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Close up

X2PJwvCxBqI42THpFdissw.text: We visited the Larder around 1 pm.  Although we really wanted breakfast (stops at 12) they have a good amount of dishes that are brunch like so it worked.  We went into the restaurant and realized after checking out the menu we were in their cousin restaurant/cafe next door which is more about coffee and baked goods.  The actual restaurant (as well next door) is cozy with a rustic feel & was full- we got lucky as a couple left 5 minutes after our arrival.   We started with a couple of coffees.  Impressed that they had an oat milk option & the Cappuccino with oat milk was excellent!  We ordered a couple of egg dishes.  Eggs Benedict & the second dish had a poached egg, cooked salmon & potatoes (can't remember the name).  The Eggs Benedict was amazing with perfectly poached eggs and smoked salmon!   You can taste and see the freshness and care that goes into each dish!  They have a map that shows where in Scotland their ingredients are sourced from.  Service was attentive & engaging.  Skip the hotel breakfast and get to this hidden gem for an unforgettable meal!

0aplh0EtUjgqw7R38gYVIA.text: A cozy place for breakfast just off the Royal Mile. The staff was friendly and the food was good.

OsVpExPVqKWRISHoIyBECg.text: Yummy quick breakfast. Good selection of coffee and tea. Pleasant vibe. Noisy. Just next door to the Radisson.

R9IU7BVt9P0UPFbYSOwENA.text: Cozy little cafe with high quality food and friendly service. I came here with my husband and three of our friends. We arrived about 10 am and had no booking. Luckily, we got a table. Through the time we were there, the cafe filled up quickly and had a few people waiting for a table. The menu had a good selection of foods big or small. My husband and I ordered the Full Breakfast and Veggie Breakfast (10-11). When it arrived, the presentation was simple and clearly thought out.  The food was delicious. The toast was generously buttered, mushroom juicy, and plate full of flavor. The vibe of the place was lovely but low-key. My only complaint would be that you leave smelling like food. The set up is an open kitchen so you can smell everything being cooked, which is nice but it does leave food odor on you the rest of the day. Still, I would recommend this place for their unique dishes, thought out presentation and nice staff.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Veggie breakfast
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Full breakfast

urSARgNfPo_F36Ci34Lnrw.text: My wife and I actually stopped into the cousin cafe right next door........ two times in two days. I still dream of the scones with butter and jam that are baked fresh and only till they last. I'm not sure what they make them out of,  but I am sure that they are a testimony that God does care about us. Also the grilled cheese sand which was amazing, rich, salty, sweet, and crunchy, gooey balanced amazingness. Yeah- that good. I would travel 15 hours again just for this place.

BT9d4qKvI40IshDBKrJECQ.text: The Edinburgh Larder: a cute modern breakfast place popular with eaters and serving up a small menu of curated Scottish takes on breakfast classics. Look for- vegetarian haggis, local salmon benedicts, and sundry Scottish breakfast items.   As it's well known for needing to wait, I was very lucky although ashamed that my friends went ahead and I showed up a bit late to waltz right into a coveted table in the small, stylish space. I started my morning with a tasty mocha, and then moved on to a classic eggs benedict which hit the spot just about perfectly for me.   The service was quick and very friendly! I would like to be back, particularly if I have friends visiting and want to bring them somewhere lovely!

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Eggs Benny!

jJFrVHevVfjxXDA4R2o-nw.text: If I could go back here tomorrow, I would. Alas, that would require a 9-hour flight and more pennies than I currently have. This was our favorite food stop along the Royal Mile - tucked away along a side street, it's easy to find and not at all touristy. Its modern takes on traditional Scottish food are delightful, and gave me the push I needed to try a few things I hadn't tried before. The presentation is beautiful. This is clearly a place that is for lucky locals and smart travelers - so which one are you? :)

Ldl5CsZk_DABT7YacVCtNg.text: This place was fabulous! The wait staff were friendly. The food was amazing! I highly recommend it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

WBloVZ_J1sAY--0bsWY8XQ.text: Best breakfast in a long time: great taste, generous portions and the amazing coffee; if you like coffee you'll love their coffee. Great service: caring, kind and ever so accommodating - no wonder there's always a cue.   Second day in a row and no change for tomorrow's breakfast.

nbZTwBmiZ3ba-FhzZGUGRw.text: Loved this place! We were seated immediately at the communal table, luckily, because there were 2 groups of people who came right after us and had to wait 20 minutes or so til someone finished and left. Small and intimate, only seats around 20. Service was friendly and fairly quick despite their being short one server. Food was amazing! We both had the eggs Florentine--eggs cooked perfectly, delicious hollandaise sauce, fresh spinach, crispy bread. Cappuccinos were some of the best we've had in Scotland! Definitely recommend eating here!

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Eggs Florentine

Q_MRULbxe5Qz-eD9aS49Gw.text: This place is amazing! It is a small farm to table restaurant and this is something starting to catch on back home, but there is nothing that is this good. This eatery using local goods. Not just produce. Everything tastes better, fresher, and cleaner. If there is a waist, total worth it. The staff is super friendly and I want to have lunch here. The decor fits the atmosphere and there is a nice laid back vibe.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

ZlaXTia_RAl97TOCZtHrxA.text: Lovely little cafe/deli. We had some bacon sandwiches which were delicious, and the americanos were fantastic. Great quick breakfast spot right off the Mile. The device was excellent also.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

oZRWHJLhheRBk6zZC7cZnQ.text: Amazing staff, delicious food. So awesome, we went once for lunch, then the next day for breakfast! It's a bit small inside, so you might end up sitting at the same table as another set of people or waiting a bit, but it's worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Cheese and chutney sandwich
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Bacon eggs Benedict

hZ-gVXeSWMrRaGc5G3EDRQ.text: Absolutely delicious. My expectations were high and the food did not let me down. Salmon toast, a mocha, and fresh banana bread. I am suggesting this to all friend's visiting Edinburgh.

xKOKQhqE27toUNn6DaDtSg.text: We couldn't get a table right away (8:45am) but had to wait 30 minutes but it was so worth it as the breakfast was fantastic! The only bad thing was that we ate here the last day in Edinburgh otherwise we'd for sure be back. Of all the places we ate breakfast at during our 7- day stay this one was definitely the best!  I ordered the 'Bacon Benny' and this was the only place (of the once I went to) where they had a real hollandaise sauce with only butter and no milk/cream added. (I have a dairy sensitivity but can tolerate butter). The homemade jam accompanying the scones were just wow!   Don't miss this place when visiting Edinburgh!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

yp2x-ZP51OsciezMbarBog.text: I am a big meat lover however this time I thought I would try something different so I ordered the vegetarian breakfast and it was delicious! It was very well flavored. Also their freshly pressed juices are highly recommended!

2LZVIzQr0OqkgLPcxmGGmQ.text: This spot was a True highlight of our visit to Edinburgh. The food was absolutely perfect. The service was wonderful. It was the best espresso I'd had in the few days I was there, and their homebaked scones are wonderful. I'm gushing but it was a diamond in the midst of all the tourist stops in the area. A+!

gq3xwwZtcxiyh6_QsUVtog.text: Worth the long walk from our hotel and was a fun stroll down the royal mile.  This is a cozy charming place for breakfast.  They made us feel welcome and the food was delicious

cnjSn8fBNmz3trACmH__1Q.text: I needed a pick-me-up after my train journey through to Edinburgh, and The Edinburgh Larder was on the way to where I was headed. It is just off the Royal Mile which meant it was filled with locals rather than tourists. The food is beautifully displayed in a glass cabinet and it was hard to resist buying something to eat. I just had a cup of green tea and enjoyed the relaxing, friendly atmosphere. I also noticed they had a nice selection of local treats like honey and oatcakes to purchase.

aWJrGOjehDmkCca1VkPI_A.text: I was just visiting but luckily have local friends who recommended this spot for lunch. After always going to very touristy spots, this was a great pick. Food was local and fresh. Service was lovely.

VBBnnp533irLKuu40whLQw.text: Despite the raving reviews this place got on Yelp, I can't say that I was impressed with my experience there.   This afternoon I decided to pop by the Larder and, I must admit, my expectations were high. Inside it was lovely, but nearly empty (hey, more room for me!). However, I was greated by the waitress in a very indifferent manner, I kinda felt as if I was disturbing her cleaning/packaging routine.  The service was kind of lackadasical but I didn't mind much anticipating great food. Well, that's where I was very disappointed. Don't get me wrong, the food was okay (no hairs in it, no dust on it), kind of. It just wasn't great. I had the pumpkin and goatcheese fritata which came with salad on the side. The fritata was ... well, ... bland really. There is no other word for it. The "salad" on the side was dressed with olive oil, that's it. No vinegar, nothing, just olive oil.  The food wasn't horrible, it was just a severe case of "I could do this ten times better at home". What annoyed me was that the plate looked as if someone had spent a great deal of time thinking of what would look pretty, but forgot to actually taste the food for seasoning and flavour.  All in all, I wouldn't go here again. It's pricey, and the food was bland to me. (Oh, and did I mention that my fritata was only warmed half-way through? The other side was still cold as it had just come out of the fridge!). Eek!  I'd give this a miss, or I just caught them on a really, really bad day!

74EJvv6vkexKUe1qOrveWg.text: It was my last morning in Edinburgh when I decided to stop in here for a tea and a bit of breakfast before my way to the airport - and I'm glad I did! It was my favourite brekky place I went to during my stay. It really is a quaint place with really lovely staff that make you feel at home. I wish we had one of these in Dublin! If I make it back to Edinburgh, I definitely will be making another visit!

_m180Uk4pVwuwefdofD_6g.text: I love the Edinburgh Larder! My husband and I went there twice in our short (2.5 days) trip to Edinburgh.   Not wanting to eat breakfast at our hotel again, I looked on yelp to find a place close to the hotel. The Edinburgh Larder was just around the corner, so off we went.  The place is small but very charming and with a nice-sized menu. For breakfast, I had the Scottish breakfast tea and scrambled eggs with smoked salmon. My husband had a bacon sandwich. Both of us were extremely pleased with the taste and quality of the food. On our way out, we picked up some honey, whiskey jam and gluten-free shortbread biscuits. The biscuits were for me, and I immediately ate one. It was definitely one of the best gluten-free cookies I've had so far, and it melted in my mouth, just like shortbread is supposed to. The honey and jam were for our parents, so I haven't tried them yet, but I'm sure they are as delicious as they look.  When we came back for lunch, I had the lamb burger. Delicious! Moist and juicy, very well seasoned. My husband also enjoyed his sandwich, but I was too busy eating my lamb to notice what he was eating.   We had good food on our trip, but the two meals we ate here were some of the best. I can't wait to return to Scotland for many reasons, but I'm definitely eating here when I do return.

1Htd5Yk2sZTXmbZPCb7_Lw.text: Went along to the Cheese and Beer night here and as unusual as it may sound was a really enjoyable night and worked really well. With some excellent cheeses' and some beers I have never tried before, (wonders will never cease) these where topped of with some amazing home made chutneys. The place itself has a lovely feeling to it very clean and welcoming. They pride themselves on local produce and the owners seemed extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic about all there products which was nice to see. I will defiantly be making this a pit stop for lunch on more than one occasion during the festival this year as it is perfectly positioned just off the royal mile. Go you'll love it!!!

sfKx1OJxJT9QdLcleGslXw.text: Went to a Qype cheese and beer event here recently and will definitely be taking my sorry little behind back again! The owner was lovely and friendly. One of the best things about Edinburgh Larder is that they use local produce and take pride in sourcing all of their yummy ingredients  good skills. My favourite cheese was the St Giles Isle of Kintyre Smoked Applewood. Definitely worth a try. This was paired with a Stewart's St Giles dark beer and strangely enough even though I'm not a fan of beer (unless I'm at a festival and have no water left to clean my teeth) I loved the St Giles beer. Definitely too good to brush your teeth with, I would actually drink that instead.

QCBwK6OhxZOm6kGxJznHrw.text: I had a brilliant time at the Qype event that was held here last week. 4 excellent cheeses (Anster mature cheddar, Loch Arthur mature cheddar, Inverloch goats cheese and Isle of Kintyre Applewood) were served up with some lemon infused rapeseed oil, three home-made chutneys and some Stewart Brewing beer (Hollyrood, Edinburgh Gold, Embra and St Giles), all held together by a very lovely and knowledgeable owner and one of the brewers from Stewarts. I'm not a beer or lager drinker, but I did really enjoy the pairing of them with cheese and it's something that I might try again at home. This was a really lovely shop, which I hope to be back in shortly, that has a great selection of produce. I especially enjoyed the spiced pumpkin chutney, which I may be misappropriating as having been made by me in this year's Christmas hampers!!

xmNTVXv7ifmHX2ZxMIphaA.text: One of my favourite places to go for lunch when Im at work. Only ever ordered the homemade soup and half sandwich deal which is 5 odd but the ingredients are always fresh and at a high standard, The soup and sandwhich always fill me up so I would recommend it. The staff are very friendly and quirky which is also a selling point. I wouldnt be able to afford to go there every day for lunch but it's a good treat once in a while.

w3wUkzQ2VDUXJHGLI1nRqg.text: Effectively a permanent farmer's market, you can tell the quality of the food at the Edinburgh Larder is going to be top-notch even before you step inside. With a lot of organic and veggie options the whimsical feel of the place is sometimes a bit much for me, but having picked up some of the most tremendous smoked mackerel known to man on a visit here, I'm prepared to overlook that one.  It's an excellent lunch spot, especially alone with a paper.

HJGdEH6L1zYehcLL5lM3Qw.text: I was also at Edinburgh Larder for the Qype tasting event, but like Arnold Schwarzenegger, I'll be back! This well-kept secret was like being in your friend's mom's 1980s kitchen; the kind of place you go where you know you'll be welcomed warmly by people who really care about what they're feeding you, and you'll get only the best of freshly prepared, honest-to-goodness home-cooked food. But this isn't the fatty Scottish food you might expect; what's on the menu here is largely determined by what they can get, as the food is all locally sourced from friends, family and neighbours  a refreshingly environmentally-friendly policy when most of our food is flown from around the world. Particularly recommended to fans of good cheese and homemade chutney, the Edinburgh Larder has a wide selection of both. The (squeaky!) smoked applewood from Dumfries was my favourite  I couldn't get enough!

dPrVDnFNirenGEKClpNYCA.text: Edinburgh Larder is ace, its so good to have somewhere that I can take visitors to experience the great food Scotland has to offer. The staff are friendly and know their products. They make amazing chutneys as well, make sure you try those! A place I will definitely return to time and time again

gSH8poql6_A_GmBguZO6Ng.text: I found this place during a massive rain storm.  We stumbled in wet and with twins and the owner and worker were more than inviting.  I had a half bree, tomato and basil sandwich with a cup of a vegetable soup.  My wife had a lamb pot pie that was amazing.  We also ordered tea and shared a scone with cream and jam.  It was one of the better experiences we had in Edinburgh and it really felt homey inside.  This is a great break for something and warm when you are filled to the brim with haggis, fish and chips and everything else deep fried.  Highly recommend this place for lunch or breakfast when you are in Scotland.

Hh4yMBUIbi1nDQGRY3ZlKA.text: Despite all the many cafes and pubs on the Royal Mile, I actually find it hard to decide where to eat nearby. It's really difficult to find a compromise between quality and value and for money. Well I recommend The Edinburgh Larder, just off from the Royal Mile.  Now this "delicatessen, cafe, gallery" isn't cheap, but I do think it's value for money. As some of the other reviewers have mentioned, this place is known as a delicatessen, selling quality local produce but "inspired by the continent". It's basically got a wide selection of meats and cheeses. Whilst impressive looking, that really isn't for me, but I did appreciate the cafe. First and foremost this place struck me as a great place for vegetarians. It isn't always easy to find veggie options in a sandwich place and when you do its usually boring egg or plain cheese. The Edinburgh Larder though has a great range of creative vegetarian (and vegan) sandwiches. Actually most of the sandwiches are vegetarian. It isn't the cheapest, and expect to pay 4 or 5, but they sure taste nice. They also offer soup, salads, and cakes.  There didn't seem to be much of a gallery when I visited, but according to the staff this has yet to get up and rolling. I look forward to it!

CsXqU6En280E1ImAAwdEQw.text: We had two very tasty smoked fish paste sandwiches in a warm and friendly athmosphere. The staff was very friendly although we arrived late (it closes at 5:00 pm).

IFU0XEG0y4n5pkiHbzHfKw.text: Myself and my boyfriend visited this for breakfast in November. It was pretty quiet and it's a lovely looking place inside.  In the end we settled on some sausages on their wholemeal rolls with tea and a coke. The coke was an organic variety which my partner didn't enjoy but that's not the larder's fault - just letting you know there's none of the traditional coca cola in this place. My tea was fab and there was quite a few cups out of the pot.  Now on to the average part. We were the only people who ordered hot food at this point and it took between 10-15 mins for the sausages. They were good and the rolls were very high quality. Don't understand what took so long though.  The cost for 2 rolls and sausage, tea and a coke was 11. I'm afraid I didn't think it was worth this. Although the slow service didn't help. I doubt I'll be back but the food was good. Just not good enough for the money.

_UvydUyAGtzSOtomwp3F4A.text: Had high hopes for my first (overdue?) visit but feel a wee bit let down, the tea was OK the milk was served in espresso cups which dribbled everywhere, the cups were none too clean and the whole place looked un-cared for, the staff paid us almost no heed. The product may be ultra responsble chic but the delivery needs attention.

XdAm7X5zcAr1MnusaMXcGQ.text: I don't write reviews much but this one is worth writing about so others can enjoy this place as well. My wife happened on this cozy place on her way to Dovecot Tapestry Studio (worth a look as well if you are visiting Edinburgh). This cafe/deli highlights authentic, local foods in a very casual, friendly atmosphere. The breads on offer are the tastiest I've had ever and do try the traditional Scottish breakfast with the "black pudding" (a kind of blood sausage if you are unfamiliar) which is very good on it's own as well.

DvNSwNj124NBByMROlcGow.text: This was my favorite meal when I went to Edinburgh! I got the veggie breakfast which was veggie haggis, a sunny-side up egg, some delicious bean thing, toast, and possibly other things I'm not recalling. So good! My friend wasn't too hungry so she just got a biscuit, but she said that was really good. The staff were very nice and the place is small and charming. I will be going back if I'm ever in Edinburgh again.

BHRyk28MR3Uh6SnDpV3dVg.text: Love this place! I was also here for the Qype event (I daren't miss a beer tasting event!!) and we were all made to feel very welcome. We were treated to a cheese, chutney and beer session with the owner discussing the various merits of the cheeses and chutneys, together with a special guest speaker from Stewart's brewery who was talking us through the beers. I'll be honest and say that I am not a massive cheese fan and I was a little but unsure if it would go with beer. However, all fears were quickly allayed as they make an amazing combination! The larder itself has a really nice, chilled atmosphere with a kind of rustic look which I thought was a really nice look. The range of products that they store (which I believe are pretty much all locally sourced) is fantastic and the owners are really nice people. The larder must have looked pretty appeasing to all the tourists as we were interrupted various times by tourists looking to join the party!! Can't say that I am down this part of town often but along with dangerousunicorn I will be dragging my lil ass down this way more often!

KKnBSpZ_WtUMt3smAR4xwA.text: Great stop  for a relaxed lunch. Got the Taste of Scotland platter which was excellent especially the salmon. Brie sandwich good also. Honey chia latte good but more like a steamer.

IZEuV_Bkb3QKXz62uC0iPw.text: Amazing authentic Scottish food! My friends and I got 3 plates to share plus 2 desserts! Definelty recommend the eggs Benedict, smoked salmon, and veggie haggis! The elderflower jello and template ice cream are also a plus to end your meal! The service is superb and the themed feel inside the restaurant makes you feel really cozy as if you are at home!

yLHIXt1MyVMI7P4WnC_L9g.text: My friend and I were staying on Blackfriars St. and, after a long day of traveling, were looking for food before exploring Edinburgh. From the outside looks of the Edinburgh Larder, it seemed like a quaint and authentic place to eat, so we decided to give it a try for late lunch/early dinner. As soon as we walked inside, each of the employees not only greeted us with a huge smile but seemed genuinely interested in where we were traveling from, giving us advice on where to visit during our time in Edinburgh. They were the epitome of hospitable and friendly to us and all the other customers, so the service was phenomenal. Nay, it was incomparable, and really set the bar high for the rest of our UK interactions.   Now, as for the food, my friend and I went straight for their cheese plates with pumpkin chutney and oatcakes. The Thistly Cross cider was also highly recommended, so we turned this late lunch/early dinner into an all-out feast. The food is sourced from all over Scotland, and I can't speak highly enough about the quality. The staff is so knowledgeable about what they're serving and how they're preparing it that, well, I wish I could eat there every day (which my friend and I did while we were in Edinburgh). Also, Thistly Cross is pretty much the most dangerously delicious adult beverage I've ever had the pleasure of enjoying, so I need to figure out where I can get my hands on it in the States.   We ended up eating there twice more during our stay, and both of those times were for breakfast. It doesn't get any better than being greeted first thing in the morning by the friendliest people in Scotland. Plus, the clotted cream and jam is always the way to go! I can't thank the Edinburgh Larder and its staff for such a memorable and enjoyable first (but definitely not last) trip to Edinburgh.   Side note to prove that the employees there are the best, love their job, and you should go there immediately if you're in Edinburgh: My friend and I were visiting in early March and the entire cafe was filled with fresh-picked daffodils. I asked who was responsible for hand picking all the flowers and, sure enough, one of the employees, Chris, had picked them all and filled the cafe with them. The Edinburgh Larder, staff, Chris and his daffodils: you all are national treasures!

AE4-U2_TOfD6vKD3Ik18JA.text: Bummed that I stumbled across this place on my LAST day in town.   The best food I had on my entire trip. No lie! All I had was the baked egg (w/cream and cheese), a coffee, and the best scone I've ever had. With clotted cream. Homemade jam. It was all amazing. Simple.  The staff is friendly and attentive.  If you're in Edinburgh, try it. Delicious!

1ipluLr-9VDRZXcYdkj2zA.text: Generous in servings and service. Delicious and affordable food. What more could one want? Go here if you like food and/or liquid.

8zQcrzymSc5aUJFygD8XMQ.text: This teeny gem offers local food assembled daily, so that their menu of salads and soups rotates based on what is available. I had the chickpea curry, served with fresh sour cream and some greens, and it had my attention. You know sometimes curries hide behind their spiciness, well this was all flavor. The waiter was super cute and shy, which made him absolutely adorable.  It was packed with people waiting- for some reason they stuffed themselves inside like their need to be filled was overflowing into a filling of something else. It made the atmosphere slightly rushed if not just claustrophobic, though I support people eating, it just made my meal measurably less satisfying. However, because it is so cute, and the people were all nice, no deduction.

pOLG0azY-KjkiqrBvh6U-Q.text: I had breakfast in the Edinburgh Larder as I left the house with a rush, and no coffee :(  The staff were so friendly and welcoming.  A new waitress was learning the tricks as it was her first day and she was nervous, but she did a great job.  I had a cappuccino and toast with jam. Now, I never have toast with jam for some reason, so I thought why not have it  now, for a change. Two large slices of toasted granary bread arrived with a little pot of butter and a tiny cute little pot of jam, which, considering its minute proportions, was only half filled. I thought it was a bit odd. Not that I could have asked for more jam, but still.  Lovely place, lovely people and nice food. Great stop over for coffee or lunch.

7MtUIjuk0QTiv9oTYnNP_A.text: Great sandwiches ! I got the goat cheese with pickled beet and added (for just a bit more) some chicken !! Soo delicious! Then I had a slice of a lovely apple and cinnamon cake! I could have another slice now ! Umm so good !

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Soup and half sandwich yum
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Delicious goat cheese and beet sandwich

xEvlyGHN0iy1WTgzD1o8KA.text: Tight space but very good food! The atmosphere is cute and the staff is friendly. It's cheap too!

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. This is the ham sandwich with cheddar cheese and chutney, comes with the house salad too!

Cx0CYvWz9xs6o8uAkB9A7w.text: Came here for brunch with some friends and enjoyed the meal. Everything is very fresh and seasonal. Service was good!

GSpFOh4Ch1sKmLJvQMtRvg.text: Pure yumness. Fast service and good Scottish food to warm your soul. Enjoyed the spot and friendly staff.

by_k3yvmIptrCy1Uq7-qFw.text: A tasty breakfast place just off the Royal Mile in Edinburgh !!!!

ZzilyYAab6FeAUJ4wp3r1Q.text: I had an artichoke soup here that I'm still thinking about many years later! Great place for a very yummy lunch & coffee!!

UGvd30LMFW9WvEa_ZqPCyg.text: I'm not even done eating here! I had the flat white, Curried Carrot and Lentil soup, and Caramelized Onion and Crowdie frittata and they were all fantastic. The staff is very kind and the location itself is tucked away from the Royal Mile, meaning it's nice and quiet. I definitely recommend coming here! The soup by itself was a meal, the frittata made me stuffed! So good :)

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Caramelized Onion and Crowdie frittata
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Curried Carrot and Lentil soup

vK4S-9EI0OA02etkLpDq2g.text: My favorite lunch spot in Edinburgh for delicious, locally sourced food. The salad plate is a beautiful  medley of the daily salads and was superb. I found this wonderfully refreshing after eating some of the heavier meats on my Scotland trip. The tea was fab, honey was even better and the service was delightful. I would eat here everyday if I could!  The desserts looked amazing but I was so satisfied after my meal I had to resist!

IA4gOKLjuqLqvc7o4snW7w.text: My wife, daughter and I stopped here as soon as we arrived in Edinburgh for our first Scottish dining experience. I was excited to have a full Scottish breakfast and this did not disappoint. Fried egg, sausage, bacon, black pudding, beans, mushrooms - it was all so delicious. Everything my wife and daughter ordered was great and the coffee was quite nice. I will be back next time in Edinburgh.

-ejSS0MGnu7tgdYLrkMCVA.text: Plenty of locals in this tiny breakfast/lunch spot. Fresh, tasty, and creative dishes filled the menu: breakfast rolls, porridge quiche, french toast. The baked eggs were heavenly and the homemade bread/toast was superb. Fresh coffee and juice were perfect too!  Just off the Royal Mile, look for the blue building!!!

8kDHV2WKaOVugSlkB6S3hg.text: The porridge and sausage breakfast roll was very much enjoyed. However, the veggie breakfast was ok. The best part of the veggie breakfast was the toast and egg. The beans were a bit hard, and while it was long ago, the veggie haggis has changed in Edinburgh. Years ago I remembering having veggie haggis that tasted just like regular haggis--I tried both last time I was in Edinburgh. In all my partner and I enjoyed the meal, however, next breakfast we will try somewhere else.

QR5Cn4tpKRaELVrG7AyOtg.text: Food is of good quality but nothing too exciting. Reliable place for lunch.

eBRJQmA1aiQM_-ZOexs72A.text: Unfortunately, they were sold out of almost everything. No bread, or soup specials left. They also had no Coke or Irn Bru, so I settled for water. I got the Fritada with Tomato, Fennel, and Brie. Good flavor, but unfortunately, it was soggy. Had a very slimy texture. The salad was fresh, and the dressing complimented it well. The barley had an ok flavor, but it was stone cold. Tried to enjoy it, but it was not tasty at this temperature. The Strawberry Cake was very good. It is homemade, and has an excellent sweetness and texture. Staff is super-friendly, and service was great. A chill environment.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Strawberry Cake.
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Fritada with Tomato, Fennel, and Brie. Also a salad and barley.
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The outside of The Edinburgh Larder.

WUEBBd3WE31ITw3pQX4ufg.text: Good place to have breakfast. If you go there, definitely have tea. They serve loose leaf tea which is amazing. I had veggie breakfast and it was very good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Veggie breakfast

nFjB5PWG73tgQPpxdp_h7w.text: Decent food, but poor service.  I had a half soup, half sandwich combo. The soup options are quite nice and the bread you get with the sandwiches is really good, but the sandwich options themselves aren't that amazing.  Service was quite poor, although it was a busy place with only two people for the ~10 tables. Nevertheless, food took 15+ minutes to get there and getting any attention from the server also took a while. Overall, for a single person, it took a bit over an hour to get in and out, which I think is too long for lunchtime.  I also watched two other tables get mixed up orders (orders going to the wrong table), so it didn't feel like it was just me getting a poor experience.  Getting takeaway might be a better option as you wouldn't have to worry about the staff so much.

qOZw0qiT3Gp-XM4cs9qCLA.text: WOOHOO wonderful!! I never thought I could enjoy an English breakfast (just being honest). Well theirs is insanely good! The meats and hell even the beans are local, and it is OBVIOUS! The sausage was insanely good. They even had a near perfect cappuccino! Folks it is BUSY and you WILL wait a bit, but it's worth it. You queue at the front door, and don't worry you won't be alone!

95ZiAjwN5eXoDQ4aDK-ybw.text: Just arrived from the overnight train, arrived at Edinburgh Larder with our 3 suitcase and two tired children and the staff couldn't have been more welcoming. Food fabulous. Wholesome, nourishing, delicious & fresh. Tea/coffee great. Will be back and we're only in town 2 days!

photos.caption: Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Proper leaf tea :)
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Great tea
Photo of The Edinburgh Larder - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Veggie Breakfast

pFMC7_00E9P5eM4x41bPSA.text: The food was pretty good.  I went simple and got the eggs, sausage, and toast.  Eggs were wonderful and the sausage was full of flavor.  My wife got the French toast and she seemed to like them.    The main reason I'm giving this place three stars is because of the service.  We waited 30 minutes to get a seat and then another hour after ordering to receive our food.  The couple next to us got tired of waiting, so they got up and left.  Breakfast shouldn't take that long to prepare.    If you don't mind slow service, then it's a good spot.

9OGdGCucrTuiICU1MKGxMg.text: Really loved their black pudding sandwiches! Soya latte also nice!

omSmUOEPDK-EpUpaWp_lUg.text: Strangely this was my first visit to the Edinburgh Larder, though it has been on my radar for the last five years... I popped in at midday today for a sunday brunch/lunch with some friends.  The Edinburgh larder is in a very central part of town, great for students, locals and tourists who are exploring the old town. There is not so much space inside and a relatively fast turnover between customers, making this not a great place to hang out with a book/laptop but a perfect place to enjoy breakfast or lunch with friends at a leisurely pace.   Mid-dissertation, I didn't really want a big meal which would make me go home and take a siesta. I opted for a soya cappuccino and a scone. I was advised that there was no more clotted cream but that this could be replaced with butter.  The coffee was good (artisan roast, a reliable local favourite) though there was no pretty coffee art as I have come to expect thanks to the incredible and competetive coffee scene in Edinburgh. The scone was pretty good, clearly made on the premises and not bought in from elsewhere. The jam also seemed homemade with some juicy berries intact.   One of my friend's order a cheese platter which looked amazing, complete with pickles, some homemade bread and a very tasty looking blue cheese.   Upon checking in on Yelp we got a 10% discount, bringing my coffee and scone down to just under 5, reasonable in Edinburgh. Some of the savoury dishes seem a little on the pricier side though the quality of the ingredients does seem to be reflected in this slightly higher price tag.  I will be back (if I have time before leaving this dear city) to sample one of the tempting cakes on offer.

rgXleDUWF_7-oR8n8okv0Q.text: Great food. Would return again. Across from a hostel tucked away a bit from the Royal Mile. Given the location it can get pretty busy. Seating is a bit tight as well since travelers often try to bring their luggage in as well. Had the vegetarian Scottish breakfast which was really tasty. Portions are good and, thankfully, so is the coffee. Had an espresso with my meal. The bread is heavenly. They also have a take away storefront as well if you don't want to stay in. Don't miss this great food establishment. Service was fast and efficient.

BilXYJeRcYJoiktFefKM1A.text: This is a generous review in my opinion. The food portion here was quite small and has a high price. The food did not stand out and could be found at any other restaurant in old town. The manager here was very friendly and gave us some help on our journey, but the other staff was a bit indifferent to our presence.

oorqbG24NtQqqwP0pjoDXQ.text: Yummmmmmmmmmmm.  It was a drizzly, grumbly day when my partner and I decided it was time to finally check out the Edinburgh Larder after some museum wandering. And I'm pleased to report that my findings were DELISH.  I will admit firstly that we meandered in post-breakfast, which both of us were a bit disappointed we missed out on. However, when I ordered the frittata (close enough to breakfasty, right?) and the very food of the gods was presented to me on a plate, I really couldn't complain. Seriously: for a frittata that was filled with barley, leeks, and other normally "meh" sounding ingredients, what I was given positively made my mouth water. Good job, guys!  My partner's soup was equally excellent, although he found the sandwich with vegetable pate (a chickpea base) just average. (Then again, he didn't dip his sandwich into the soup... mistake? Probably.)  Coffee was also good. But man. That frittata, y'all. I mean dang!

qugi5z907T5aXryNNQb4Mg.text: Great food in the heart of Old Town. There is limited seating and tables are very close together, but definitely the perfect place for brunch!

sN4hqcyiCbpshRtfOuB3xA.text: Head here immediately. Absolutely fresh and delicious local produce. I wish I had found this on my first day in town! Had the best meal i had all week in Edinburgh: purple potato salad, fresh beet hummus, fresh pesto, aubergine, lentils, pomegranate slaw, etc. Can't recommend enough!

uhcQcwzDESRcMcnIT2BMpw.text: I've been meaning to come to Edinburgh Larder for ages, and finally stopped by the other day for some lunch. This was a great idea!  Aside from delicious food at a decent price, there are other things I'll focus on. I have become very wary of eating meat at cafes and restaurants lately as I'm concerned with animal welfare (dirty rotten hippy, I know). I asked about their pork and chicken, and they could tell me exactly which farms they got their meat from and what their practices are as far as making sure their animals are humanely treated. This put my fears to rest and I was able to enjoy a meat platter and a soup with my wife, both of which were absolutely delightful.  The coffee was serviceable - and certainly better than most eateries - but nothing to shout hurrah for in my own opinion. Then again: This is an eatery, not a coffee shop, so this is not a huge concern.  There isn't a lot of space in the Larder, and I saw at least one group waiting outside for a while until they could get a seat. It's hard to fault them for not having a bigger venue, but it could get kinda cramped.  The staff were very patient and friendly and were not at all fazed by my questions. All in all, a great lunch experience and I wouldn't hesitate to go back.

_s9NkkUQVUH78XQUYp3JAg.text: A great place to stop in while touring around the Royal Mile. The ingredients were very fresh and delicious. The bread on my sandwich was perfectly soft without being soggy and my tea was served perfectly. It has a homey feel, but is still light and airy. The staff were very friendly but kept the tables moving during a very busy lunch hour.

VdsPck1S9ozLgNmA0NAIvA.text: Excellent lunch with fresh, farm sourced ingredients. We had soup -carrot coriander- and half sandwich. The soup was delicious and the half sandwich was as well. I had the salmon and my husband had a mushroom and pesto. Both were terrific. The atmosphere is cozy and the staff friendly. It was recommended to us by a local and it was a hit with us. It is right off the Royal Mile round the corner from the Radison. You won't be disappointed.

tJk_SLiF5JXva0PddJfkng.text: Delicious, locally sourced food! We had homemade granola, yogurt, and an almond croissant. The espresso was strong and yummy. I'd definitely go back again!

uLje7i1gT6yz3T9uUauS9A.text: I stopped by here to take-away some lunch into the lovely sun, as a freshly made sandwich sounded like a winning idea. It is a wee place with a very home-like feel and the staff was really lovely. I ordered half a salmon sandwich and my friend ordered the goat cheese sandwich, both were made in timely manner and wrapped nicely for an easy carry. The bread was absolutely super fresh and light sourdough and the combination of the salmon and capers on it was delicious. They have lots of gluten free things and a range of salads and they offer soup, so lots to choose from. Their display case of cakes and salads together made it all look too wonderful and I definitely will go back for lunch and or a tasty treat!  On another note, I have been back a few times during the week around lunch time and they are always packed. It isn't worth it to wait around, as seats do not come up very quickly. The staff are lovely, but generally they can't give an accurate wait time because people mill around, so you often will wait 25-30 minutes or longer for a table, especially on the weekends. I would highly recommend take away!

IqyxEIKYTUKYoaItJ7HIYQ.text: Excellent food, cheery staff, and a deliciously wonderful atmosphere. It's small and crowded and sweet. I loved that all the food was local and seasonal.

HbkKGm0mrCUpIkrgu4UvCA.text: Fresh, creative, healthful food, in a charming restaurant. Excellent service, reasonable prices, we came back the next night for more and were not disappointed!

MC87efEuuxgLB0fH9SsWGA.text: Fantastic find! The porridge is the best I have ever had - delicious toasted almonds! All the baking (scones, croissants, cakes) look fabulous! Coffee is divine!
